item.title: Ticket #1577 (New Hook: future_post) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Future-dated posts should really get their own hook, for a variety of reasons.

The attached patches create a new action, 'future_post'. These patches prevent publish_post from being triggered on future-dated posts.

1.5.1.3 and 1.6 patches included.

item.title: Ticket #1432 (get_archives_link breaks HTML validation) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description: Wouldn't it be better if the value of format is 'nonxhtml' (or html4, or something like that) instead of 'html'? The latter is too general, because developers are used to refer to xhtml as html, just as a habit.

item.title: Ticket #1540 (Date format returned by wp_get_archives is not localizable) updated
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description:
We could easily fetch also the unix timestamp of a post in that month from the database and then form the string using the date_i18n function with an internationalized date format: 

$text = date_i18n(_('F Y'), $arcresult->post_date);

However, in this situation we could run into some problems. The string marked for internaliozation is 'F Y' (which means: monthname year). For example I want to translate it as '\a\r\c\h\i\v\e \f\o\r\: Y F', but somewhere in Wordpress the same combination 'F Y' is used and it is again internationalized. If the second occurence of 'F Y' is in other context (far apart from archives) then our translation will be totally inadequate.

Actually, using the same string in many contexts is far more general gettext issue and maybe is its greatest flaw...

item.title: Ticket #1499 (add_option shouldn't always check db for pre-existing option) updated

item.title: Ticket #1499 (add_option shouldn't always check db for pre-existing option) updated

item.title: Ticket #1574 (Timestamp and 'ago' should be in single translatable string) created
item.dc:creator: nbachiyski
item.description: In some languages the term 'Some time ago' needs rewording, so that the translation of 'ago' comes before the timestamp. In wp-admin/index.php (the dashboard) the timestamp and 'ago' are two different translatable items, so the translation of ago could not be put before the timestamp.

item.title: Ticket #1572 (Changeset 2766 breaks TinyMCE in non-Safari) created
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
The commented line in rev 2766 is the payload of the if() statement on the previous line.

When the if is false, the editor is not initialized. Unless you're using Safari, it's false.

Fix: Expand the comment to include the preceding if().

item.title: Ticket #1571 (Can't upload images using MarsEdit, mo:blog, etc) created
item.dc:creator: miffo
item.description:
I tried to upload images to my WordPress installation but it doesn't seem to work, all images seems to be corrupted.

What happens is that I use MarsEdit to upload the images and if I directly try to access these images I get an error message similar to "PNG Error: [5C][30][0D]I: invalid chunk type" (same thing seems to happen for jpg). If I log into the server and check the image files they seem to have been corrupted in some way, I checked the content using an hexeditor and there are changes at the beginning of files as well as in other places.

Thinking this was a problem with MarsEdit I tried submitting pictures from my Palm using mo:blog but the result is the same. I then thought that there was a problem with my server (a debian installation) and asked if other had the same problems on the MarsEdit mailing list and it turned out that others had the same problem.

I'm using WP 1.5.1.3 (it wasn't possible to select this from the popup)

item.description: Ah, you get to add the file *after* you create the ticket.

item.title: diff.txt attached to Ticket #1570
item.dc:creator: alexkingorg

item.title: Ticket #1570 (Comments RSS Feed: remove limit on page/post feeds) created
item.dc:creator: alexkingorg
item.description:
I couldn't figure out how to upload my patch, so here it is: 

33,34c33,34
< 			comment_author_url, comment_date, comment_date_gmt, comment_content, comment_post_ID,
< 			$wpdb->posts.ID, $wpdb->posts.post_password FROM $wpdb->comments
---
> 			comment_author_url, comment_date, comment_content, comment_post_ID,
> 			$wpdb->posts.ID, $wpdb->posts.post_password, $wpdb->posts.post_title FROM $wpdb->comments
38c38
< 			ORDER BY comment_date DESC LIMIT " . get_settings('posts_per_rss') );
---
> 			ORDER BY comment_date";
42c42
< 			$wpdb->posts.ID, $wpdb->posts.post_password FROM $wpdb->comments
---
> 			$wpdb->posts.ID, $wpdb->posts.post_password, $wpdb->posts.post_title FROM $wpdb->comments
52c52
< 		<title>by: <?php comment_author_rss() ?></title>
---
> 		<title><?php comment_author_rss() ?> on '<?php echo $comment->post_title; ?>'</title>

item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

wp-includes/default-filters.php line 69 defines a filter to apply on get_the_excerpt:

add_filter('get_the_excerpt', 'wp_trim_excerpt');

item.title: Ticket #1519 (RSS Update Frequency) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

MAGPIE_CACHE_AGE defaults to one hour (line 575 of wp-includes/rss-functions.php).

Anything more than 15 minutes is too frequent. And if someone adds other feeds into their dashboard, they run a very real risk of being blocked from that feed in the future.

item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status, Milestone changed

lines 306 and 309 of wp-includes/template-functions-general.php:

$text = sprintf('%s %d', $month[zeroise($arcresult->month,2)], $arcresult->year);

I don't see a clean way to use the blog's preferred date format; maybe someone else will.

item.description: add two new parameters to get_archives(): orderby and sort

item.title: Ticket #247 (Sort get_archive() output by more than just post_date) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
Version, Component, Milestone changed

Here's a better patch for get_archives() and wp_get_archives() that introduces two new parameters:

orderby - defaults to post_date

sort - defaults to DESC

Existing templates should not break as these parameters are added to the end of get_archives().

item.title: Ticket #1568 (Install should supply a nickname for the admin user) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
The install process does not create a nickname for the admin user, which renders the greeting at the top right a little weird:

Howdy, . [Sign Out, My Account]

Attached is a patch that will define a display name for the admin user at install.
